The President must report to Congress on the implementation of United Nations Security Council Resolutions 1695, 1718, and 1874, while the Director of National Intelligence must report on China's implementation of these resolutions within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of National Intelligence must report to Congress on China's compliance with United Nations Security Council Resolutions 1695, 1718, and 1874, as well as any assistance provided to North Korea by China. SEC. 10. REPORT ON REFUGEES FROM NORTH KOREA ADMITTED TO THE UNITED STATES. The Secretary of State must report to Congress on the number of North Korean citizens admitted as refugees every 30 days for 5 years. Failure to submit the report on time will result in a $250,000 penalty. SEC. 11. SENSE OF CONGRESS AND GAO REPORT ON IMPLEMENTATION OF NORTH KOREAN HUMAN RIGHTS ACT. The Sense of Congress is that the US has not adequately implemented the North Korean Human Rights Act and the President should increase efforts for a transition to democracy in North Korea. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report to Congress on the implementation of the Act by the Secretary of State within 90 days. The report required by Public Law 110-346 must include an assessment of the implementation of section 203 of the North Korean Human Rights Act from 2005 to 2009, focusing on assistance provided outside of North Korea. The report must assess funds used by the Secretary under section 203 and evaluate the effectiveness of implementing title III of the North Korean Human Rights Act, focusing on protecting North Korean refugees. The report evaluates funds used by the Secretary under section 203 and assesses the effectiveness of implementing title III of the North Korean Human Rights Act, with a focus on protecting North Korean refugees. It also includes an assessment of the Secretary's facilitation of applications by citizens or nationals of North Korea for admission to the United States as refugees. SEC. 12 amends the North Korean Human Rights Act to state the policy of the United States on human rights in North Korea. SEC. 13 emphasizes the presence of the Special Envoy for Human Rights in North Korea in negotiations. SEC. 14 authorizes appropriations for ground-based missile interceptors. In addition to previous appropriations, $160,000,000 is authorized for the Department of Defense in fiscal year 2010 to deploy 44 ground-based missile interceptors at Fort Greely, Alaska. Additionally, there is an authorization of appropriations for the development of a variant of the F-22 advanced tactical fighter for sale to the government of Japan. Authorization of appropriations for the development of a variant of the F-22 advanced tactical fighter for sale to Japan and repeal of the prohibition on funding for the sale of F-22 fighters. Authorization of $50,000,000 for Radio Free Asia and $25,000,000 for National Endowment for Democracy to expand radio broadcasting and support civilian broadcasts to North Korea. The Secretary of State will reallocate $10,000,000 from the Bureau of East Asian and Pacific Affairs to the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights, and Labor within 30 days of the enactment of this Act. The funds will be used for programs to advance human rights in North Korea.
